children.subject: ^And by that I mean, the courses that declared majors usually Phase II, that we should Phase I instead?

Non-majors will not be able to enroll during phase 1 or phase 2 (same as before).  They will only be able to waitlist.  Those non-majors who waitlist during phase 1 will be dropped from the waitlist at the end of phase 1.
Thank you!

Does #2 mean that non-CS/EECS majors, assuming they enroll early enough to not be on the waitlist, will permanently hold a spot in that class? If so, does that mean the courses that we usually Phase II, like 170, we should Phase I for fear of lack of space?
Graduate CS courses require the permission of the instructor who can give that permission based on any criteria s/he chooses.
^ does this apply to graduate-level CS courses?

And the choir responds: "Amen!"  

(Still, it's not exactly fair to say they haven't fixed any of the problems or even that the system hasn't adapted to any of our requirements.  It's unclear that the additional things we need to implement our previous enrollment policy will ever be implemented.  Instead, it is more likely that the department will have to develop a policy that accommodates the limitations of the product campus purchased.  That will be done in time for F17 enrollments but may end up being similar to the current stop gap measure.  The "improvement" from F16 to SP17 is only that we know what the system will or won't do now and so can make this announcement now instead of just surprising people by kicking them off waitlists with little or no warning.)

While I am sure you and the rest of department are working day and night on this, is it really true that there hasn't been enough time, of all things, to resolve this? These are the same issues as last semester. Can the new student information system really not adapt to ANY of the department's requirements when it's been months since the last enrollment period? Why was it chosen as the replacement? Supposedly they "tested" it and received input on it extensively before it was implemented. It just doesn't seem to make any sense that there would be this many problems, with literally none of them resolved, if it truly took as long as they say it did to get it up and running. I realize I'm preaching to the choir here, but it just baffles me...
tomorrow
Tomorrow morning for some people.
When does enrollment Phase 1 start anyways?
Yes.
Does #2 mean students who plan to declare CS at the end of Fall 16 should wait until Phase 2 to waitlist in any upper div CS class, and not waste Phase 1 units on them? Thanks!

@1173 while plausibly applicable for future spring declarations and fall enrollments is unfortunately not applicable in the present moment.  (Note: Your #2 in your timeline is inaccurate as clarified in earlier conversation on this thread.)

For fall enrollments, phase 1 ends 9 weeks AFTER spring finals. For spring enrollments, phase 1 ends four weeks BEFORE fall finals.
Alright, thanks. So is this the only difference between fall and spring enrollments? Are there any other differences to note?

To clarify, unlike in Spring, phase 2 happens before the semester is over, so it is very likely that the waitlist will be purged before we process apps, and therefore #4 in the timeline posted by anon is also incorrect. The timeline looks something like the following:

1. Students send in their application for the CS major during Fall 2016 (their last semester of fulfilling prerequisites) before the last day of the semester 

2. declaring students sign up for tech electives/ee 16a/other lower division requirements and CS/EECS majors sign up for CS upper divs in phase 1

3. phase 1 ends, CS upper div waitlists are purged of non-majors

4. phase 2 starts (Nov 14), non-majors can get on the waitlist and stay on

5. once grades are released to us, we start processing apps, and students are accepted into the major (late December/early Jan)

So does this mean that the second procedure is a deviation from last semester's policies? According to Lily Zhang in @1173, last semester (Spring 2016) "waitlists [are] purged after we process major apps". Assuming the same is the case this semester, doesn't this mean that students who are declaring the CS major in Fall 2016 and who know that they will be admitted can still waitlist upper division courses in Phase I?

From what I can tell, the timeline would be as follows:

1. Students send in their application for the CS major during Fall 2016 (their last semester of fulfilling prerequisites).

2. Students (successfully) sign up for upper division CS courses through CalCentral (as mentioned to be possible in this post).

3. The CS Department processes the major apps of these students and accepts them to the major.

4. The purging of non-majors takes place after the processing of major apps (as mentioned in @1173), but no longer applies to these students, who've now been accepted to the major.

Is this correct or I am mistaken? Is the information in @1173 still valid for the current semester? Are there multiple purgings of the waitlist? Has fall enrollment changed from spring enrollment? If so, what precisely are these changes? 

Thanks!
Read the first follow up discussion on this thread.

"While the new campus system will allow non-CS/EECS majors to sign up during phase 1, the department will purge the waitlist at the end of phase 1 of all non-majors"

What does "sign up" mean? Does this mean that if non-majors enroll into the upper division courses (and are not put on the waitlist) in Phase I, they will remain enrolled after The Purge? Or are enrolled non-majors also purged?
It doesn't necessarily mean that. It means that we can look at what supply and demand are for courses new majors are interested in once phase 1 is over or almost over.
What do the CS department advisers advise us to do?
(for Phase I and beyond)

Our advice hasn't really changed despite the change in systems: In this limbo semester for students declaring this fall, sign up for tech electives/ee 16a/other lower divs/requirements in phase 1, and wait until phase 2 to sign up for CS upper divs. Basically pretend the cal central doesn't allow you to waitlist for CS upper divs in phase 1.

Oh, we can sign up for EE16A now? I didn't know this before.

Thank you!!
mostly yes, see EE enrollment policy here: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/eecs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy

We are second-year Letters & Science students declaring Computer Science this semester and we have completed all our CS/Math lower-division courses and all our L&S breadth requirements. Does this mean we can't Phase I any CS upper division courses or EE16A? What are we supposed to do?
Just to clarify I understood the enrollment policy correctly - a 2nd year undeclared L&S (CS intended) can phase 1 waitlist for EE 16A?
yes, please waitlist.

I am a second year L&S undeclared CS. I tried to waitlist for EE16A but it says:

Error: Request not processed. There is no wait list available. The wait list request was not processed, as there are no wait list places available for one or more of the class sections in this request.

I did choose the waitlist option. What am I doing wrong?
pls try again if you haven't already. likely, your section was full, but sections have been expanded

How much of the waitlist is actually going to be accommodated...

I think it'd be a terrible idea to waste Phase I units on a class that you aren't actually going to get in, especially since most of the Piazza posts seem to suggest that second year L&S undeclared CS students (like you) are LAST on the priority list. Is it even worth waitlisting?
Would this mean that people declaring fall 2016 would not be able to get into most CS upperdivs like 170/188 for spring 2017?
I also had this problem even though enrollment is not full for 189 and 161 yet :(
Same issue
I'm sure Michael-David will update the other thread that mentions this issue @2352, so please check there tomorrow/Thurs.

It turns out this is merely another way the new course enrollment system conspires to increase the stress of undergraduate students and department staff.

Here is what happens (edited for clarity) according to central campus project staff -- thanks Lydia for researching this:

As soon as any student adds to the wait list of a particular course (say a non-major for a CS upper div --, all students who try to enroll in that class (including student who should be able to enroll) are prompted to add to the wait list. Then, when the wait list process runs, students who do qualify to enroll in the class are enrolled. The class will then open back up and students who meet the reserve cap will be able to enroll until another student adds to the wait list.

As of yesterday morning, the wait list process had not yet run for Spring 2017 but it seems like it must have done so yesterday evening.  When the process runs, students who meet the reserve cap will be enrolled (provided they don't have any time conflicts or haven't reached the unit max for Phase 1).

I'm EECS major, but when I tried to enroll in CS189 and CS161, I was put on the waitlist while my friend got directly enrolled in the course. I'm pretty sure there are still hundreds of seats available in those two courses....

history.content:
We  haven’t had time yet to come to develop a coherent enrollment policy that works for CS upper div classes with the new post-telebears campus enrollment system .  Here is what we plan  to do for SP17. 

 

1)     In phase 1 and Phase 2, all declared CS/EECS majors will be able to enroll directly into upper division CS courses assuming space is available. Note:  We will still only enroll up to 70% of estimated final class capacity until (U)GSI hiring is finalized enough that we are sure the instructional staff can support higher enrollments in that particular class.

2)     While the new campus system will allow non-CS/EECS majors to sign up during phase 1, the department will purge the waitlist at the end of phase 1 of all non-majors (including students who may be planning on declaring the major at the end of Fall 16).  Non-majors will be able to get on (and stay on) upper division cs class waitlists beginning in phase 2.  Non-majors will be able to enroll into upper division classes during the adjustment period.
history.subject: Spring 17 Enrollment Procedures for Upper Div COMPSCI Classes
